intro: Sanicula erythrophylla, commonly known as red-fruited sanicula, is a perennial herb native to the United States, particularly found in the eastern regions. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes caraway and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant features a slender, branching stem with opposite, pinnately compound leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, greenish-yellow flowers are arranged in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family, and it produces reddish berries that are a distinctive feature of the species. Sanicula erythrophylla is typically found in moist, shaded woodlands and thrives in rich, loamy soils.
